column12: it is one of the most densely populated regions in the country and is the second most populous federal subject. The oblast has no official administrative center; its public authorities are located in Moscow and Krasnogorsk (Moscow Oblast Duma and government)

column2: with some hills with the height of about 160 meters (520 ft) in the western and extensive lowlands in the eastern part. From the southwest to northeast
column3: the oblast is crossed by the border of the Moscow glacier to the north of the common ice-erosion form with moraine ridges
column4: and to the south – only erosional landforms. The western and northern parts of the oblast contain the Moscow Uplands. Their average height peaks at about 300 meters (980 ft) near Dmitrov and the upper point of 310 meters (1
column5: 020 ft) lies near the village of Shapkino in Mozhaysky District. The northern part of the Moscow Uplands is steeper than the southern part. The uplands contain lakes of glacial origin
column6: such as Lakes Nerskoye and Krugloye. To the north of the Moscow Uplands lies the alluvial Verhnevolzhsk Depression; It is marshy and flat with the height varying between about 120 meters (390 ft) and 150 meters (490 ft).To the south stretches a hilly area of the Moskvoretsko-Oksk plain. Its greatest height of 254 meters (833 ft) lies in the area of Tyoply Stan
column7: within the Moscow city limits. The plain has clearly defined river valleys
column9: and occasional karst relief
column10: mostly in Serpukhovsky District. In the extreme south
column12: lies the Central Russian Upland. It contains numerous gullies and ravines and has average height above 200 m with the maximum of 236 m near Pushchino.Most of the eastern part of Moscow Oblast is taken by the vast Meshchera Lowlands with much wetland in their eastern part. Their highest hill peaks at 214 meters (702 ft) but the average heights are 120–150 meters (390–490 ft). Most lakes of the lowlands
column13: such as Lakes Chyornoye and Svyatoye
column14: are of glacial origin. Here lies the lowest natural elevation of the region
column15: the water level of Oka River at 97 meters (318 ft).

column1: Moscow Oblast is located in the central part of the East European craton. Like all cratons
column2: the latter is composed of the crystalline basement and sedimentary cover. The basement consists of Archaean and Proterozoic rocks and the cover is deposited in the Palaeozoic
column3: Mesozoic and Cenozoic eras. The lowest depth of the basement (1
column4: 000 meters (3
column5: 300 ft)) is to the south of Serebryanye Prudy
column6: in the very south area of the oblast
column9: 800 ft)) is to the east of Sergiyev Posad
column10: in the northeast region.Tertiary deposits are almost absent within the oblast. Significantly more abundant are deposits of the Carboniferous and Jurassic periods. In the Cretaceous period
column11: a sea was covering Moscow Oblast
column12: as evidenced by phosphate deposits and a variety of sands. Cretaceous sediments are most common in the north of the oblast. The sea was wider in Jurassic than in Cretaceous period. Typical Jurassic deposits
column13: in the form of black clay
column14: are found within and around the city of Moscow and in the valley of the Moscow River. Carboniferous deposits in Moscow Oblast are represented by dolomite
column16: and marl. Coal deposits rich in organic remains occur in the south
column18: and in the western regions. Devonian deposits were also found within the region.Quaternary deposits are widely distributed in Moscow Oblast; their thickness decreases from the northwest to southeast. It is believed that there were four glaciations in the area. The first occurred in the Lower Pleistocene and spread to the east-west part of the Oka River valley
column19: it left almost no trace in the region. In the Middle Pleistocene
column20: there were two powerful glaciations. The Dnieper glacier covered a large part of the Russian Plain
column21: whereas the Moscow glaciation stopped just south of the present city of Moscow. The last glaciation
column23: occurred in the Late Pleistocene; it did not directly affect the territory of Moscow Oblast
column24: but left traces in the form of fluvioglacial deposits
column25: mainly in the north area. The glaciers left behind a moraine loam with pebbles and boulders of various rocks
column30: limestone and sandstone. Its thickness varies between a few meters at watersheds and 100 m at moraine ridges.

column1: Moscow Oblast is rich in minerals. Sands from the sediments of different periods (mainly Quaternary and Cretaceous) are of high quality and are widely used in construction. Quartz sand (milled quartz) is used in the glass industry
column2: their production is conducted from the end of 17th century near Lyubertsy. Much of the production is currently halted due to environmental concerns
column3: and only the Yeganovskoye field is being exploited; its silica sand reserves are 33 million tonnes and annual production reaches 675
column4: 000 tonnes. Sand and gravel deposits are abundant within the Smolensk-Moscow Upland. Sandstone deposits are developed in Klinsky and Dmitrovsky Districts.

column1: There are numerous clay deposits within the oblast; fusible clay is excavated in Sergiyev Posad. The Yeldiginskoye field near the village of Sofrino has reserves estimated at 30 million cubic meters; its annual production reaches 600
column4: 000 cu ft). Refractory white clay occurs in the eastern region
column5: in the Carboniferous and Jurassic sediments
column6: and is extracted from the 14th century near Gzhel. The largest (Kudinovskoye) deposit is near the town of Elektrougli with the reserves of 3 billion tonnes. Also widespread are loams which are used in brick manufacture and limestones ("white stone"). The famous Myachkovo deposit of carboniferous limestone provided material that went for cladding of such buildings in Moscow as the Bolshoi Theater. The mining in Myachkovo had been stopped and currently
column7: limestone is provided by the quarries of Podolsky
column9: and Kolomensky Districts. The latter district also provides marble-like limestone.Other industrial minerals of Moscow Oblast are dolomite
column10: limestone tuff
column11: and marl; mostly in the southern and eastern parts. Dolomite is used in the cement industry. Its mining is concentrated mainly near Shchyolkovo
column12: the reserves exceed 20 million tonnes and the annual production is about 650 tonnes.Phosphates are produced in the Yegorevskoye and Severskoye fields. Meshchera and Verkhnevolzhsk Lowlands are rich in peat. The largest mines are "Ryazanovskoe" (840
column15: both around Yegoryevsk. There are deposits of brown coal beyond the Oka River

column1: Salts of potassium salt are being developed around Serpukhov and Yegoryevsk. There are also numerous mineral springs near Zvenigorod
column3: and Serpukhov. They include surface springs and reservoirs at the depth of 300–500 meters (980–1
column4: 640 ft). Deeper
column5: at 1–1.5 kilometers (0.62–0.93 mi) there is a large sea of salt extending beyond Moscow Oblast. Waters with the salt concentration up to 300 g/L are used in the local food industry and spas.

column1: The climate of Moscow Oblast is humid continental
column2: with clearly expressed seasonality – short but warm summers and long
column3: cold winters; the continentality increases from northwest to southeast. The period of the average temperature below 0 °C (32 °F) lasts 130–150 days
column4: beginning in early or mid-November and ending in late March (or very early April). The average annual temperature varies from +3.5 °C (38.3 °F) to +5.5 °C (41.9 °F). The coldest months are January and February with the average temperature of −9 °C (16 °F) in the west and −12 °C (10 °F) in the east. With the arrival of arctic air
column5: the temperature drops to below −20 °C (−4 °F) that may last up to twenty days during the winter
column6: with the temperatures reaching −45 °C (−49 °F). The minimum temperature of −54 °C (−65 °F) was observed in Naro-Fominsk. Thaws often occur in December and February due to the Atlantic
column7: and rarely the Mediterranean cyclones. The thaws usually last several days
column8: and their total number from November to March can reach fifty. Snow starts accumulating in November
column9: though sometimes in late October or early December
column10: and disappears in mid-April (sometimes in late March). The snow depth is 25–50 centimeters (9.8–19.7 in) and the soil freezes to 65–75 centimeters (26–30 in). The warmest month is July with the average temperature of +18.0 °C (64.4 °F) in the northwest and +20.0 °C (68.0 °F) in the southeast. The maximum temperature of +40 °C (104 °F) was recorded in Kolomna during 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves. The average annual rainfall is 450–650 millimeters (18–26 in)
column11: the precipitation is maximal in the northwestern and minimal in the southeastern regions. The summer precipitation is usually 75 millimeters (3.0 in)
column12: but severe droughts occur once in 25–30 years
column13: with less than 5 millimeters (0.20 in) of rain over June–August.

column1: There are more than three hundred rivers with the length above 10 kilometers (6.2 mi) in Moscow Oblast. All rivers are calm and have well-developed valleys and floodplains. They are mostly fed by melting snow and the flood falls on April–May. The water level is low in summer and increases only with heavy rain. The rivers freeze over from late November until mid-April. The only navigable rivers are the Volga
column3: and the Moskva River.Most rivers belong to the basin of the Volga
column4: which itself only crosses a small part in the north of Moscow Oblast
column5: near the border with Tver Oblast. The second largest river of the region is the Oka. The northern part of Moscow Oblast includes such Volga tributaries as the Shosha
column9: and the Yakhroma. On the south flow the tributaries of the Oka
column10: including the Nara
column12: and the Lopasnya Rivers. The Moskva River
column13: which almost entirely flows within the oblast
column14: also belongs to the Oka basin. The eastern and northeastern regions
column16: are irrigated by the tributaries of the Klyazma River
column17: which itself is a main tributary of the Oka.The Moscow Canal crosses the northern part of Moscow Oblast through the Ikshinskyoe
column20: and Pestovskoye Reservoirs. In the basin of the Moskva River
column25: providing Moscow with drinking water.There are about 350 lakes in the oblast
column26: almost all are shallow (5–10 m) and many are of glacial origin. The largest are Senezh (15.4 square kilometers (5.9 sq mi)) and Svyatoe (12.6 square kilometers (4.9 sq mi)) whereas the deepest (32 meters (105 ft)) is Lake Glubokoye in Ruzsky District. There are also many marshes
column27: especially within the Meshchersk and Verkhnevolzhsk lowlands.

column1: Moscow Oblast lies within the zone of forests and steppes with forests covering over 40% of the region. Coniferous (mainly fir) trees dominate the northern (Verkhnevolzhsk lowlands) and western parts (Mozhaysky
column3: and Shakhovsky Districts). Forests of Meshchora consist primarily of pine; in waterlogged lowlands
column4: there are individual alder forests. Central and eastern regions have coniferous-deciduous forests with the main tree species of spruce
column5: pine
column7: and aspen often mixed with bushes of hazel. To the south lies the subzone of broad-leaved forests of oak
column9: maple and elm. Moscow-Oka Upland is the transition zone which is dominated by spruce
column10: for example
column11: in the upper reaches of the Lopasnya River. Valleys of the Oka are covered in pine forests of the steppe type and the far south regions (Serebryano-Prudsky and partially Serpukhovsky Districts) are cultivated steppes with occasional lime and oak groves.The intensive cutting of Moscow region forests in the 18–19th centuries reduced them and changed their species: conifers were replaced by birch and aspen. There is almost no logging nowadays and the forests are being restored

column1: Swamps are prevalent in the eastern areas

column3: but some foreign species flourish
column4: such as Canadian maple. Endemic species include water caltrop and lady's slipper.

column1: The territory of what is now Moscow Oblast had been inhabited for more than twenty thousand years. Numerous mounds and settlements from Iron Age were discovered there. Up to the 9–10th centuries
column2: the Moskva River basin and adjacent lands were inhabited by Finno-Ugric peoples. Slavs populated the area only in the 10th century. In mid-12th century
column3: the lands became part of Vladimir-Suzdal Principality. Several important cities were founded around that time
column4: including Volokolamsk (1135)
column5: Moscow (1147)
column7: and Dmitrov (1154). In the first half of the 13th century
column9: including the Moscow area
column10: was conquered by the Mongols.In the 13th century
column11: the land around Moscow was part of Grand Duchy of Moscow
column12: which subsequently was the center of the unification of Russian lands
column13: in particular the Mongol raids. In 1380
column14: from Kolomna the prince Dmitry Donskoy led his troops to defeat the Mongols at the Battle of Kulikovo. The southern part of Moscow Oblast was then part of the Principality of Ryazan; it was attached to Moscow only in the 1520.

column2: Moscow Governorate was established by the decree of Peter the Great; the area included most of the present Moscow Oblast. The Battle of Borodino
column3: which decided the outcome of the French invasion of Russia was fought in 1812 near Mozhaysk.

column1: Industries developed in Moscow Oblast in the 17–19th centuries. They were centered in Bogorodsk
column3: and Orekhovo-Zuyevo and were dominated by textile production. The first railway in Russia was constructed in the Moscow Oblast in 1851
column4: connecting Moscow and Saint Petersburg
column5: and in 1862 the line to Nizhny Novgorod was opened.

column1: Agriculture has a relatively minor role in the economy of the Oblast. Only 25% of land is cultivated and another 15% are used for other activities such as livestock farming. Agriculture is the least developed in the northern
column2: eastern and western border regions. In the southern region
column3: especially south of the Oka River

column5: especially wheat
column8: and significant role plays potato. Greenhouses are very common and Moskovsky city hosts the largest greenhouse complex in Europe. Also grown are flowers and mushrooms. Livestock farming predominates over the crop
column9: and is primarily aimed at the production of milk and meat. In addition to cattle
column10: commonly bred are pigs and chickens.The economic crisis of the 1990s in Russia had severely affected the agriculture of Moscow Oblast. In particular

column14: livestock and poultry by 30%; milk by 2 times and eggs by 4 times.

column1: Moscow Oblast has a dense transport network
column3: railways and waterways along the largest rivers
column4: lakes and reservoirs. Land routes are radially diverging from Moscow and crossed by one railway and two highway rings. Neither railways nor roads
column5: built for the most part many years ago
column6: can cope with the steadily mounting traffic flows. About half of the roads are overloaded and three quarters do not meet modern requirements. Insufficient width of the roads and frequent repairs cause traffic jams.Moscow Oblast has the highest density of railways in Russia. Eleven major radial lines originate in Moscow and run through the Oblast; the total length of the railways reaches 2
column7: 700 km. Almost all railroads are electrified. The largest rail hubs are Orekhovo-Zuyevo and Bekasovo. Regular navigation is carried on the rivers Volga
column9: as well as on the Moscow Canal. Major river ports are in Serpukhov and Kolomna. Also well-developed is pipeline transport. There are two major oil lines
column10: two natural gas rings and numerous radial lines connecting Moscow with the largest gas producing regions of the country.Moscow and Moscow Oblast have several international passenger airports
column13: Domodedovo and Ostafyevo. There is also Bykovo Airport
column14: which is used for freight. The largest military airport is Chkalovsky (near Shchyolkovo) which also processes some civilian passenger and cargo flights.

Moscow Oblast was awarded three Orders of Lenin
column3: 17 December 1956 and 5 December 1966.

column1: The highest executive organ is the Government of Moscow Oblast. Eighteen ministries act as the executive bodies of state authority. The powers
column3: functions and competence of the Government are defined by the Charter of the Moscow Region. The Governor of the Moscow Oblast will be elected with the term of 5 years. The Regional Duma of Moscow Oblast was formed on 12 December 1993. It consists of 50 deputies also serving a 5-year term.Sergey Shoygu was elected as Governor of Moscow Oblast in April 2012 by the Moscow Oblast Duma. Shoygu left office after only six months with his appointment when he was appointed as Minister of Defence by Vladimir Putin. Andrei Vorobyov was appointed as acting governor and won a full term to the office in the 2013 elections.

column1: Moscow Oblast has a high density of scientific research institutions

column7: Dubna and Protvino (nuclear physics) and Pushchino (biology). Moscow Oblast hosts Mission Control Centers for spacecraft (in Korolyov) and military satellites (Krasnoznamensk)
column8: as well as a number of test sites.
